moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 Be7 4. Bc4 Bh: All the games started here, with White to play.
moves.8. d5 Ne5: Ducking forward. In general, I'm trying to be less passive in my games.
moves.11. Bb5+ Nd7: Now I have to retreat to interpose against the check.
moves.12. g3 Bf6: Here I have to retreat. There are no available squares to advance to.
moves.14. Qxf3 O-O: Finally, I tuck my King safely away [and incidentally unpin my Knight.]
moves.15. Ke2 Rc8: Preparing to challenge White's powerful central Pawns.
moves.16. Raf1 c6: Attacking the advanced QP. White goes in for the exchange.
moves.17. dxc6 bxc6: Now his B must move. I was expecting 18 B-R6, forcing my Rook to move, but he chooses a straight retreat.
moves.18. Bd3 Nc5: Moving the Knight to a further-advanced position.
moves.19. Bc4 Ne6: I'm hoping White thinks I'm only moving here to block the Bishop's diagonal...
moves.20. g4 Nd4+: ...and overlooks my real intentions. He did, and I reveal them now with a rooyal fork.
moves.22. Rxf3 Bg5: White has a little bit of fight left in him...
moves.23. Rd3 Qe7: ....but now he calls a halt, graciously resigning.
